Tested:
1. Traspose.
2. Use 1st. row as headers.
3. Unpivot others but "Measure".
4. Rename "Measure" column as "Year".
Explanation:
1. To create year-over-year reports, we need a "Year" column. We achieve that by transposing the table.
2. The 1st. row of the transposed table will have the headers. The unpivot operation won't work as expected if the headers doesn't have their proper name.
3. Unpivoting all columns except "Measure" will separate "Revenue", "Overheads" and "Cost of goods" column values by year, which is exactly what we need to work on the reports.
4. I think this is the only option that makes sense at this point, since we can create year-over-year visualizations in the report itself, sorting by that field in the visualization. Changing the data type of that field to "Date" causes all year values to be displayed with this format: (8 | 9 | 10 | 11 |12)/07/1905

All three options A, B, and D can be used to surface videos from Microsoft Stream in a Power BI dashboard, depending on your specific requirements and the resources you have available.

Option A, using the "Video" tile, is a straightforward method for embedding a video directly into your dashboard, but it only works if the video is publicly accessible on the web.

Option D, using the "Web content" tile, allows you to embed any web content, including videos from Microsoft Stream. This approach is more flexible than using the "Video" tile because it allows you to embed any web content, but it requires copying the embed code for the video from Microsoft Stream and pasting it into the tile configuration.

Option B, using the "Custom streaming data" feature, allows you to create a real-time dashboard that displays data from various sources, including video streams. This approach may be more complex and require additional resources, but it offers the ability to display the video in real-time along with other data sources.

So, the correct option depends on your specific needs and resources.
